posts.cooked: Anyone who has tested hooks on the chain, do you think the ‘normal’ type of hooks used on fixed bars work well enough, or is something different recommended? I am also interested in knowing how much they slide down from the higher sides.

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked:
Our team is doing something very similar, and we have well tested strait down grabbing, where the chain is made to actively grind and push against the hook to slide into place.

The biggest difference is that we have a double sided hook in an M shape

IMG_9253 1170×2532 495 KB

IMG_9253 1170×2532 495 KB

IMG_9253 1170×2532 495 KB
A question for both you and @trixydevs : How large did you make the slot(s)?

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.custom_user_title: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.cooked: Our final one is 3/8, (being built). The prototype was a bit under, (slotted with a nominal 3/8 endmill) and fit great.

posts.name: Jim Barstow
posts.cooked:
I like this design… A word of caution for other teams considering this however…

If you plan on a design like this for multiple hooks vs a single hook, be very familiar with the game manuals rules about shortening the chain, G416.  If there is a slack loop between the two hooks, it could be a violation of this.

posts.name: Nicholas
posts.cooked: As of right now the slots are .3 inches.

posts.name: chrisrin
posts.cooked:
JimB1918:

If you plan on a design like this for multiple hooks vs a single hook, be very familiar with the game manuals rules about shortening the chain, G416. If there is a slack loop between the two hooks, it could be a violation of this

What about 2 hooks but only one with the slot that locks to a chain link? That should be ok, I think.

posts.name: Jim Barstow
posts.cooked: Yeah, as long as one of them can slide on the chain I would think this would be fine.
